fields.headline: Hallé/Mark Elder/Andrew Gourlay – review
fields.bodyText: Sally Beamish's second cello concerto, The Song Gatherer (here receiving it's UK premiere), was written for Robert Cohen and inspired by the wanderings of the cellist's grandfather, a Polish Jew who became a speculator in the South African diamond rush. The sombre, modal piece wove together recollections of Yiddish lullabies, Chassidic chants and a plaintive Polish folk song imploring the white stork – a symbol of good fortune – not to fly south for the winter. Though billed as a cello concerto, Hallé harpist Marie Leenhardt played almost as much of an active role. Mark Elder placed her directly behind Cohen's shoulder, from where she rarely allowed the soloist a moment's peace; perhaps the true definition of harping on. Perplexingly, when the harp finally fell silent at the start of the third movement, a percussionist began battering out a Nielsenesque snare tattoo. Cohen played with gloriously lyrical tone, yet bore the slightly pained expression of an artist trying to concentrate through the distractions going on around him. Elder not only promotes promising young conductors, he shares the platform with them as well. Andrew Gourlay is the latest in an impressive roster of Hallé assistant conductors that has included Rory Macdonald and Edward Gardner; and for his debut Gourlay chose a beguiling, rarely heard tone poem by Dvořák, The Wild Dove. Towards the end of his life, Dvořák crafted four "orchestral ballads" from a Czech collection of fairytales entitled The Garland. The White Dove is a lugubrious murder ballad, which Gourlay animated with haunting finesse. We will undoubtedly hear more from him. Why we don't hear more of Dvořák's late ballads is a mystery. Broadcast on Radio 3 on 7 December at 7pm.
